description: Integrating security practices into the software development lifecycle.
reference: CISSP CBK Domain 8: Software Development Security

description: Structured process for developing software, including security considerations.
Planning, Requirements, Design, Development, Testing, Deployment, Maintenance.
Incorporating security at every phase of the SDLC.
Identifying and prioritizing potential threats to a software system.
Threat modeling framework: Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiation, Information Disclosure, Denial of Service, Elevation of Privilege.
Process for Attack Simulation and Threat Analysis, a risk-based threat model.
All possible points where an attacker can exploit a software system.
Writing software to minimize vulnerabilities, e.g., input validation.
Checking user inputs to prevent vulnerabilities like SQL injection.
Attack injecting malicious SQL code to manipulate databases.
Attack injecting malicious scripts into web applications.
Attack tricking users into performing unwanted actions.
Attack exploiting improper memory management to execute arbitrary code.
Injecting malicious code into an application to alter its behavior.
Exposing internal objects, allowing unauthorized access.
Vulnerabilities allowing attackers to bypass authentication mechanisms.
Securely handling user sessions to prevent hijacking or fixation.
Stealing an active session to gain unauthorized access.
Forcing a user to use a predetermined session ID to exploit it.
List of the most critical web application security risks.
Analyzing source code for vulnerabilities without execution.
Testing running applications for vulnerabilities, e.g., via web scanning.
Combines SAST and DAST, analyzing code during runtime.
Inputting invalid or random data to find application vulnerabilities.
Examining source code to identify security vulnerabilities.
Guidelines like OWASP Secure Coding Practices for developers.
Standards like NIST 800-53 or OWASP for secure development.
Protecting software applications from vulnerabilities and attacks.
Defining security needs during the requirements phase of SDLC.
Guidelines like least privilege and defense-in-depth for software.
Granting software only the minimum permissions needed to function.
Using multiple security controls to protect software systems.
Software defaults to a secure state if misconfigured or fails.
Keeping software design simple to reduce vulnerabilities.
Checking every access request to ensure authorization.
Security not relying on secrecy of software design.
Requiring multiple conditions for access to critical functions.
Minimizing shared mechanisms to reduce risk of unauthorized access.
Ensuring security measures in software are user-friendly.
Linear SDLC model with sequential phases, less iterative.
Iterative development model emphasizing flexibility and collaboration.
Agile framework with sprints and iterative development cycles.
Integrating security into DevOps for continuous secure development.
Development and operations collaboration for faster software delivery.
Automating code integration and deployment with security checks.
Tracking and controlling changes to software code and configurations.
Managing changes to source code, e.g., using Git.
Isolating applications to prevent malicious code execution.
Security technology embedded in applications to detect and block attacks.
Protects web applications by filtering and monitoring HTTP traffic.
Allowing only approved applications to run on a system.
Blocking known malicious applications from running.
Building APIs with security controls like authentication and encryption.
Protecting APIs from vulnerabilities like injection or broken authentication.
Protocol for authorization, allowing third-party access to resources.
Authentication layer built on OAuth 2.0 for identity verification.
Weakness in software that can be exploited by attackers.
Standardized identifiers for known software vulnerabilities.
Framework for rating the severity of software vulnerabilities.
Applying updates to fix vulnerabilities in software.
Tracking and securing software libraries and dependencies.
List of components and dependencies in a software application.
Ensuring open source components are free of known vulnerabilities.
Software libraries providing secure cryptographic functions.
Protecting data in transit and at rest within applications.
Removing or escaping harmful data from user inputs.
Managing errors in software to avoid exposing sensitive information.
Recording application activities for security monitoring and compliance.
Protecting user sessions with secure cookies and timeouts.
Cookies with attributes like HttpOnly and Secure to prevent attacks.
Mitigating XSS by restricting sources of content in web applications.
Restricting web pages to interact only with same-origin resources.
Allowing controlled access to resources across different domains.
Evaluating software for functionality, security, and performance.
Testing individual components or functions of software.
Testing interactions between software components.
Ensuring new changes do not break existing functionality.
Simulating attacks to identify software vulnerabilities.
Automated scanning to identify software weaknesses.
Tools like Burp Suite, OWASP ZAP, or Fortify for application testing.
Tool for web application security testing and penetration.
Open-source tool for finding vulnerabilities in web applications.
Ensuring software meets security and quality standards.
Storing source code with a third party for continuity or recovery.
Managing risks from external software or libraries.
Protecting software from risks in development and distribution.
Ensuring software is deployed with secure configurations.
Configuring software to minimize vulnerabilities, e.g., disabling unused features.
Securing containerized applications, e.g., Docker, Kubernetes.
Protecting distributed, modular application architectures.
Securing applications designed for cloud environments.
Protecting applications using serverless architectures like AWS Lambda.
Ongoing updates and monitoring to ensure software security.
Applying updates to fix security vulnerabilities in software.
Securely decommissioning software to prevent residual risks.
Ensuring confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data in software.
Using cryptographic techniques to protect data in applications.
Designing software with security controls and principles.
Educating developers on secure coding and best practices.
